i
 I. 	PROGRAM SUMMARY
 
The following is the Third Progress Report for the collaborative
 
IEF-CeSSIAM project "Increasing the Availability of Dietary Vitamin 
A to Under-Six-Year-Olds through Natural, Plant Food-sources of 
Provitamin A," (ProvitA), covering the four month period of May 
through August, 1991.
 
A. 	Project Components
 
The following report will describe completed activities under each
 
of the project components with supporting documents cited as 
appendices. The four components of the project are identified as:
 
1) 	 Capacitating the laboratory at CeSSIAM in analysis of human 
plasma for retinol concentrations (HPLC);
 
2) 	 Chemical analysis for total vitamin A activity of important 
selected plant foods; 
3) 	 Effecting food-distribution intervention with important 
selected plant foods, and;
 
4) 	Evaluating the biological and behavioral impact within
 
household units of the food intervention.
 
The schedule of events is attached as Appendix 1, Time Calendar.
 
B. 	Personnel t
 
The persons contributing during this time period are listed in 
Appendix 2, List of Persons Involved.
 
II. 	 THIRD PROGRESS REPORT (TRIMESTER) ACTIVITIES FROM MAY THROUGH 
AUGUST, 1991.
 
A. 	Headquarters
 
* Transfer of project funds to Guatemala for CeSSIAM-related 
components (#1,2,4) and IEF-related components (#3) for expenses 
through the reporting period.
 
* Procurement of project related supplies and equipment included a 
four-wheel drive pick-up purchased in the USA and shipped to 
Guatemala, cryogenic vials for blood collection and storage, and an 
Eppendorf micro-centrifuge.
 
* Mr. John Barrows met with Dr. Noel Solomons, Dr. Gustavo 
Hernandez-Polanco, Dr. Jesus Bulux, Licda Eugenia Saenz de Tajada, 
and IEF Honduras staff Maria Antonieta Dominguez-King, Victoria 
Alvarado and Dr. Marylena Arita during the International Vitamin A Consultative Group (IVACG) meeting held in Guayaquil, Ecuador, June 
17-22, to discuss IEF project activities. * Mr. Jack Blanks met with CeSSIAM Staff and IEF-Guatemala staff in 
June and in July, to discuss project activities. ­
* Mr. John Barrows met with Mr. Joseph B. Coblentz, Director of 
Food Security Programs, Planning Assistance, Washington, D.C., on 
May 19th to discuss Planning Assistance involvement with INCAP. 
* Dr. Francis Davidson, Office of Nutrition, USAID, Mr. Robert 
Pratt, VITAL, Dr. Jose Mora, VITAL, Ms. Mary Lineham, VITAL, and
 
Ms. Michele Dreyfuss, VITAL, met with Mr. Jack Blanks and Mr. John 
Barrows at IEF headquarters on August 9th to discuss IEF activities 
in Latin America.
 
* Mr. John Barrows organized the completion of the third quarterly 
report for submission to the Office of Nutrition, USAID. 
B. Guatemala
 
i. 	 Component #1: Capacitating the laboratory at CeSSIAM in 
the analysis of human plasma for retinol 
concentrations (HPLC). 
The primary staff of 	this component are, laboratory analysts, Licda 
Isabel de Ramirez and Licda Ma Eugenia Romero.
 
* Licda Isabel Ramirez and Licda Ma Eugenia Romero have been 
closely following routine maintenance procedures for the Beckman 
Gold System High-Performance Liquid Chromatograph established by
 
Ing. Jorge Perez and Dr. Frank Morrow. Local engineer, Jorge 
Perez, made two supervision visits to inspect and service the 
Beckman System Gold 	HPLC.
 
* Based on the recommendations of Dr. Frank Morrow made during his 
first on-site visit (See 2nd Quarterly Report) an Eppendorf micro­
centrifuge was purchased and delivered. The micro-centrifuge will 
be used for the sedimentation of samples and extracts.
 
* A second recommendation of Dr. Morrow was to gain access to a 
spectrophotometer with capacity in the ultraviolet wavelength in
 
order to determine the retinol concentrations of the standards used 
in the daily assaying of plasma. Neither CeSSIAM nor the Hospital 
de Ojos y Oidos has a functioning spectrophotometer and the 
estimated costs to purchase one ($2,500-3,000) are beyond the 
current budget. As an alternative measure Licdas Ramirez and 
Romero have obtained permission to use a spectrophotometer in a 
nearby laboratory on the days of retinol assays.
 
* A third recommendation of Dr. Morrow was to develop inter­
laboratory quality control standards (between Guatemala and the 
USA). Dr. Morrow at the Nutritional Evaluation Laboratory, USDA,
 
Boston, has been working on the development of a freeze-dried 
(lyophilized) concentrated quality control standard to be sealed in 
hermetic ampules and later diluted on-site in a developing country
 
laboratory. Since the retinol concentration is previously
 x;i 
established in the reference laboratory, i.e., Boston, it 
represents the USA laboratory reference standard. It is hoped that 
this will simplify the "split-sample" analyses which is the current 
practice of maintaining inter-laboratory standardization with a, 
sibling laboratory in the USA. 
* In the process of establishing the Beckman System Gold HPLC 
system, Licda Isabel Ramirez and Licda Ma Eugenia Romero visited
 
several commercial and research laboratories in the Guatemala City
 
area that were using this technology. As a result of these 
communications, common problems in the use of HPLC were identified
 
and discussed by the various technicians. Upon the initiative of
 
the ProvitA project these persons decided to form an "HPLC-Users
 
Club" with the purpose to discuss on a regular basis issues of 
technique and maintenance, and to share common experiences.
 
* Technical assistance was provided by CeSSIAM staff and students 
to the International Eye Foundation, Guatemala, Vitamin A for Child 
Survival project in Alta Verapaz. A team consisting of Dr. Ivan 
Mendoza, Dr. Carmen Yolanda Lopez, Licda Ma Eugenia Romero, Ms 
Aura-Marina Guerrero and Mr. Tim Anderson collected 499 plasma 
samples from preschool children for retinol analysis. These 
samples will be analyzed for retinol concentrations on the CeSSIAM 
HPLC. See Appendix #3, Cover Letter and Report on Baseline Field 
Activities, Alta Verapaz (Spanish).
 
* Technical assistance was provided by CeSSIAM staff to the 
International Eye Foundation, Honduras, Vitamin A for Child
 
Survival project in Tegucigalpa, Honduras. A team consisting of 
Dr. Ivan Mendoza, Dr. Marylena Arita, and Licda Ma Eugenia Romero
 
spent ten days with IEF staff and Ministry of Health counterparts 
in the collection of 538 plasma samples from preschool children for 
retinol analysis. In addition, 144 children were sampled for 
conjunctival impression cytology for later analysis in Guatemala.
 
See Appendix #4, Report on Baseline Field Activities, Tegucigalpa
 
(Spanish).
 
The plasma samples will be analyzed in Honduras in the Toxicology
 
and Environmental Contamination Laboratory using the Ministry of 
Health's HPLC. Licda Romero and Dr. Mendoza made direct contact
 
with the MOH technicians in charge of retinol analysis. IEF-
Bethesda obtained a chemical retinol standard for this laboratory
 
from Dr. Morrow in Boston.
 
Planned Activities for Third Reporting Period
 
* Dr. Morrow, scheduled to make a second on-site training 
consultancy September 3-8, postponed his visit due to scheduling
 
problems. This visit will be rescheduled for the purpose of 
overseeing the extraction and HPLC analysis of the plasma samples
 
collected in Alta Verapaz.
 
* In October and November Licda Isabel Ramirez will take a -leave of 
absence from duties at the Hospital de Ojos y Oidos and CeSSIAM to spend six to eight weeks in Boston. The purpose of the visit will 
be to 1) participate in the analysis of carotenoids and retinol in
 
the baseline samples from the three hamlets of Santa Cruz Naranjo
 
using a method of plasma analysis developed by Dr. Neil Craft at
 
the U.S. National Institute of Standards, and 2) gain exposure to
 
a broader experience with HPLC techniques in other laboratories 
within Tufts University. 
ii. Component #2: Chemical analysis for total vitamin A 
activity of important selected plant 
sources. 
The primary staff of this component are, research physicians, Dr.
 
Carmen Yolanda Lopez-Palacious, and Dr. Jesus Bulux.
 
* Dr. Carmen Yolanda Lopez worked for 18 months on an ethnobotanic 
study in Alta Verapaz on the use of edible green plants. On July 
11 and 12, in-preparation for the definitive collection of plants 
to be analyzed for component #2, Dr. Lopez visited Alta Verapaz to 
identify the locations and providers of certain unusual plants in 
the food system. On July 16-17, Dr. Lopez, Dr. Mendoza, and Licda 
Romero travelled to Alta Verapaz to collect nine species of 
indigenous plants, while on July 17, Licda Julieta Quan, Licda 
Lilian Portocarrero, Sra Aura-Marina Guerrero, and Sra Blanca Pena 
remained in Guatemala City to collect specimens of the principal 
plants (carrot, sweet potatoes, "quilete") as well as other common
 
edible green and yellow vegetables from local markets. 
Each specimen was weighed to about 100 grams. One-third of the 
samples of each species were fresh frozen; one-third were blanched
 
(steam-treated) for 2 minutes; and one-third were blanched (steam­
treated) for 5 minutes. The blanched specimens were weighed post­
blanching. Plant tissues were placed in airtight plastic bags and
 
quick frozen on dry ice. Using the permission from the USDA Animal 
and Plant Health Inspection Service (APHIS), the specimens were 
identified with their botanical names and transported by Dr. Lopez
 
to North Carolina on July 18 for analysis.
 
* The lessons learned from this exercise were that fresh frozen 
plants liberate enzymes from their matrices that degrade the 
carotenoids. This forced the NCSU analysts to 'extract the un­
blanched carrots, sweet potato, and quilete on arrival. For 
analyzing plants without thermal treatment, shipment of plant 
specimens requires either shipment of refrigerated non-frozen plant 
tissue (a procedure not permitted by the APHIS authorities), or to
 
have the plants extracted in the country of origin and transported 
in sealed, gassed, and frozen vials as extracts. These procedures
 
will be considered in any future analysis activities.
 
* On July 19, the staff and students of the Food Chemistry 
laboratory of Professor Steven Schwartz in the Department of Food
 
Science at the North Carolina State University began the
 
extractions of the carrot, sweet potato, and "quilete." Details of the procedures and 	 analyses are found in Dr. Schwartz's report. 
See Appendix #5A., Cover Letter and Report to IEF/CeSSIAM.
 
In addition, the original data prepared by Dr. Lopez (Spanish and
 
English) during her stay in North Carolina are included as Appendix 
#5B., Report by Dr. 	Carmen Yolanda Lopez.
 
Planned Activities for Third Reporting Period
 
* Sixty samples remain in the freezers at NCSU Food Chemistry 
Laboratory of the Department of Food -Science. These include a 
number of exotic indigenous wild plants of the Alta Verapaz food 
system. Those that were fresh-frozen without blanching are 
irreversibly damaged, but the two-thirds that are heat-treated are 
preserved for future analysis. An extension of the existing 
agreement with NCSU to allow for the continued analysis of these 
samples will be explored. 
* Based on the experience of the collection and analyses of plants 
at the NCSU, Dr. Lopez will begin drafting the text of the "Manual 
on Field Collection of Plants for Vitamin A Analysis" with 
assistance from NCSU.
 
iii. 	Component #3: Effecting food distribution intervention
 
with important selected plant foods.
 
The primary staff responsible for this component are Dr. Gustavo
 
Hernandez-Polanco and Licda. Guisela Leche.
 
* Dr. Gustavo Hernandez-Polanco and Licda Guisela Leche made 
contacts with regional officials of the Province of Santa Rosa, 
Municipal officials of Santa Cruz Naranjo, and all local officials. 
* The four-wheel drive pick-up truck was purchased in the USA 
through Bethesda and shipped to Guatemala. Dr. Polanco processed
 
the vehicle through customs and licensing procedures (provisional). 
Insurance is paid by 	the National Committee for the Blind and Deaf. 
* Dr. Polanco and Licda Leche completed the final arrangements for 
the purchase of carrot, sweet potato, and "quilete" (Macuy). The 
carrots and sweet potato will be purchased from Institute of 
Agriculture Science and Technology (ICTA) and the "quilete" will be 
purchased from a local distributer.
 
The vegetables will be delivered by the providers to the Robles 
Hospital on Mondays and Fridays from where they will be transported 
to Santa Rosa. In Santa Cruz Naranjo three locally hired persons
 
will weigh and pack the vegetables for distribution on Tuesdays and 
Saturdays.
 
cv,
 * To provide additional incentives for participation in the 
communities surrounding Santa Cruz Naranjo, the NCBD's Program for
 
the Prevention of Blindness under Rosa Amalia Vasequez, Chief of
 
Social Workers at the Hospital de Ojos y Oidos, organized a three
 
day (July 15-17) training session in cooperation with health and
 
school officials from Santa Cruz Naranjo. Twenty health and school 
officials from the township and three surrounding hamlets received
 
training elements of visual acuity screening and ocular
 
inspection. During July and August these persons, with assistance 
from the NCBD, examined all willing community persons. All persons 
in need of further examination were identified for a subsequent 
formal rural eye health campaign to be conducted by a Ocular Health 
resident and a mobile clinic unit from the Hospital de Ojos y Oidos 
scheduled to take place during September and October.
 
Planned Activities for Third Reporting Period
 
* The intervention routine will begin by October 7, 1991 and will 
continue for a 12 month period of time. 
iv. Component #4: Evaluating the biological and behavioral
 
impact within household units of the food 
intervention.
 
The primary staff responsible for this component are Dr. Jesus 
Bulux, research physician, Lic Hector- Gamero, Nutritionist, and 
Licda Eugenia Kena Saenz de Tejada, Medical Anthropologist
 
(collaborator).
 
* Initial contact was made with the regional officials of Santa 
Rosa Province in December, 1990. Prior to the interview stage of
 
the study Dr. Bulux, Lic Gamero, Licda Saenz de Tejada, and six 
anthropology undergraduate students of the University of del Valle 
made further contacts with local municipal officials of Santa Cruz 
Naranjo and the surrounding hamlets of El Teocinte, El Naranjo, and 
Don Gregorio.
 
* During the period of June 1-12, six anthropology students from
 
the Universidad del Valle participated in an obligatory
 
Anthropology Field Studies Course designed by their professor Licda 
Eugenia Saenz de Tejada, a consultant to the project. Included as
 
an appendix is a copy of the Course Description Outline describing
 
the objectives and content of the anthropology module designed by
 
Licda Eugenia Saenz de Tejada. See Appendix #6, Anthropology 
Module Course Description (English/Spanish).
 
From June 3-11 the students participated in the organization of the 
study communities, pilot testing of the survey questionnaire, and
 
a general orientation to the importance and role of vitamin A.
 
From June 17 through July 12, the students were in the field
 
completing structured interviews in all households with children
 
under six years old in the three communities. Two students worked
 
0z in each of the three hamlets. Included as an appendix are a report 
from Licda Sanez de Tejada, a report by the students on their activities with initial results, and an accompanying variable code 
book. See Appendix #7A,B,C. (English/Spanish).
 
* The use of undergraduate students was a very positive experience. 
Not only did the students prove themselves to be effective data­collectors (the students in fact completed the survey one week earlier than planned), but the students gained practical field experience, and the project has established a valuable relationship with the Universidad del Valle. This same exercise'will be 
repeated at the one-year follow-up.
 
* Lic Hector Gamero and Dra. Marylena Arita drafted and revised a 
24-hour dietary recall questionnaire that will be used periodically during the intervention phase of the project. See Appendix #8, 
Dietary Recall Questionnaire. 
Planned Activities for Third Reporting Period
 
* As a continuation of the baseline (biological) survey in early 
September, a one-fourth sample of the population of Don Gregorio, 
which has been chosen to be a "control" (no intervention), will be 
selected and plasma samples collected by Dr. Mendoza. The same 
offering of deparasitization with an anti-helminthic drug will be 
offered for all children under six years of age in the hamlet. 
* As a continuation of the baseline (dietary) survey in El 
Teocinte, a number of households with preschool children who have 
not been contacted in the Dietary Survey appeared for blood 
sampling. In September, Lic Hector Gamero will return to this 
hamlet and perform dietary interviews on these members, therefore, 
expanding the population sample. 
* The intervention is due to begin on October 1. In October and 
November, the repeat 24-hour dietary survey will be conducted by
Lic Gamero and Dr. Arita in the intervention hamlets of El Teocinte 
and El Naranjo, among the households enrolled at baseline.
 
* In September baseline survey data will be coded, entered and analyzed. In October and November, Lic Gamero and Dra. Arita will return to the communities to observe and interview families 
participating in the plant intervention for aspects of use of the
 
vegetables in their diet.

CHILD SURVIVAL PROJECT IN THE DEPARTMENT OF ALTA 
VERAPAZ, GUATEMALA
 
Attached, for inclusion in the progress report for the
 
second trimester of the PROVITA is the INFORME DE LA EJECUCION
 
DE LA EVALUACION INCIAL (LINEA BASAL) [REPORT ON THE EXECUTION
 
OF THE INITIAL, BASELINE EVALUATION] FOR THE VITAMIN A -CHILD 
SURVIVAL PROJECT IN THE DEPARTMENT OF ALTA VERAPAZ, GUATEMALA. 
It is relevant to the PROVITA process, insofar as the 502 
retinol samples will be analyzed in Guatemala, on the high
 
performance liquid chromatography at CeSSIAM.
 
Described is the proccess of obtaining the various
 
variables, including the sampling of biological variables
 
(anthropometry, hematocrit, plasma for retinol) that was our
 
domain.
 
Attached as annexes are the 1) the forms for data
 
collection and 2) the preliminary results of the population
 
hematological survey including age, gender and hematocrit by
 
community.

'Al
 INTRODUCCION:
 
A finales del aRc 1990 e inicios de 1991 se reali'z6 la 
planificaci6n de la Linea Basal del proyecto. Para el efecto se 
Ilevaron a cabc una serie de reuniones dirigidas a definir
 
Indicadores de estado nutricional de vitamina A, a utilizar en
 esta etapa; fecha de realizaci6n de la misma y recurses 
necesarios para su desarrollo. En dichas reuniones participaron 
funcionarieas de IEF del nivel central y profesionales del CNPCSG-
IEF a nivel local.
 
Se acord6 utilizar cuatro indicadores de estado nutricional: 
a) Niveles de retinal en plasma; b) Ingesta diet~tetica de 
vitamina A; c)determinacion de hematocrito y d) Antropometria. 
Se consider6 importante tener informaci6n socioeconomica de las 
comunidades y los recursos agricolas con que se cuentan para el cultivo de vegetales. 
Con el propsite de obtener mayor participaci6n de la 
comunidad, en la linea basal y en las actividades posteriores del 
prayecto se decidi6 efectuar la linea basal en dos etapas, la 
primera, que se realiz6 del 13 al 24 de mayo --en la cual 
especificamente se evitaron procedimientos invasivs--, se 
efectuaron encuestas sobre cuatro aspectos: socioeconmicos; 
agricolas; ingesta diet~tica de vitamina A en preescolares y 
estado de salud (incluyendo medidas antropom6tricas, peso y 
talla). 
En la segunda etapa, del 1 al 12 de julio, se efectu6 un 
nEncuesta Hematol6gica", que fue la extracci'n de muestras de 
sangre para anAlisis de retinal y determinac iones de hematocrito. 
Aunque no estuvo contemplado al inicio, se efectu6 en una 
submuestra un examen fisice para eval uar sarcoptiosis e 
infecciones de piel sobreagregadas. Se di' tratamiento 
antipgrasitaric (pamoato de pyrantel) se y posteriormentehicieron exAmenes macrosc6picos de heces en busca de ascaris 
lumbricoides. 
Este informe contiene en forma resumida las actividades

CARACTERISTICAS DEL MUESTREO: 
A) TAMAr10 DE MUESTRA: 
El CAlculo del tamao de muestra se hizo tomando come 
variable de interds la prevalencia de ni':s c'n deficiencia de 
vitamina A. Se tcm6 com referencia de la prevalencia en el Area 
de Alta Verapaz, dos estudios previes realizades per CESSIAM en 
ni Ros preescolares, durante los aRes de 1987- 1988. En dichs 
estLdic's la prevalencia de niRos c'n niveles de retinol menores 
de 30 ug/dI fue de 60 X, en 1997 y alrededer de 40% en 1988. 
Para el CAIculo se consider' el valor minimo (40%). Se acept6 
una confiabilidad de 95 %,(a = 0.05.) y un limite' de error de 
0.04. El tamaRo de la poblaci.n se estim' en las cuatro 
comUni dades seleccionadas en base a dates reportados per 
Municipalidades 2 institulciones oficiales y no gubernamentales a 
nivel local. Se estim5 que un 20 X de la peblaci6n podria 
corresponder a nines menores de sets aRos.

 Si gui endo este enfoque se hirc el calculc, del tama~c de

f6rmul a:
 
TamaRo de muestra -n /(1+(n/pcblacion))

donde:

El nfmero minimc calculade con este procedimiento, fue de

En el documento adjunto se informa sobre las actividades 
realizadas para la evaluaci6n inicial (Linea Basal) del Proyecto 
de vitamiana A, de la Fundaci6n Internacional del Ojo (IEF)/ 
Honduras. 
Dr. Noel U. Solomons. (CESSIAM-Guat emala*

Li c. Victoria de Alvarado (IEF- Honduras)

Q-1 INFORME DE'ACTIVIDADES RELACIONADAS CON LA EVALUACION INICIAL
 
PROYECTO VITAMINA A, DE LA FUNDACION INTERNACIONAL DEL OJO CIEF).
 
TEGUCIGALPA, HONDURAS. 1991.
 
A) PLANIFICACION:
 
La planificaci6n de la evaluaci6n basal, especificamente de 
retinal shrico y citologia de impresi6n conjuntival (CIC), se 
raliz6 en la ciudad de Guatemala, con participaci6n de la Licda. 
Victoria de Alvarado (coordinadora del proyecto), Licda. Maria 
Eugenia Romero, Dra. Marylena Arita y Dr. IvAn Mendoza 
(profesionales de CESSIAM). Se discubieron indicadores, tamaKo 
de muestra y necesidad de recursos materiales y humanos. (ver 
anexo 1) .
 
B) EJECUCION:
 
La ejecuci6n de la linea basal, se llev6 a cabo del 27 de
 
mayo al tres de junio del alo en curse. Durante el primer dia 
(27-5-91 se relizaron actividades organizativas: a)revisi6n de 
material y equipo de laboratorio: b)reccnocimiento del Area de 
trabajo y c)capacitacion de personal en aspectos especificos para 
la toma de muestra de sangre y citologia ocular. A partir del 
dia 28 a] 31 de mayo, se reljz6 la toma de muestras en el campo. 
El dia res de junio se discutier-on aspectos relacionados con 
andlisis y almacenamiento de muestras. 
B. 1) PERSONAL: 
El ECIuipo de brabayo estuvo integrado por personal de IEF; 
Ministerio de Salud P'iblica (MSP>, y CnenLr:o de Esbudios en 
'y Sensori opat {as, Senectud, Impedimentos Alteraciones Metab6licas 
tGESSIAM::. En el anIe..o Q , ,se amp1 1 a in formac i6 n sobre el 
personal partici pante y SUS funciones durante la linea basal. 
B.2) SELECCION DE LA MUESTRA: 
Las 21 comunidades objeti ve del proyecto, se encuentran 
distribuidas en cuabro grupos; las comunidades de cada grupo 
corresponden a la jurisdicci 6n de un "CESAMO" (Centro de 
Sal ud). Todas las comunidades perLenecen al Area periurbana de 
Tecucigal pa. Grupo 1: CESSAMO Las CrucItas, que cubre ocho 
Lomunidades; Grupo 2: GESSANO 3 de Mayo, incluye cinco 
comunidades; -Grupo3: CESSAMO can Franci sco, cubre ci nco 
comlnIdades y Grupo 4: CESSAMO Alemania, con tres comunidades. 
ParE la seleccion de los sujetos para la toma de muestras de 
sangre se hizo un muestreo estratificado, bomando en cada 
comunldad un ndimero proporc1onal a] Laman de la poblac i6n. Las 
enadres fueron citadas a un cenLzro d, :poraci1oCnes (que s'? describe 
abajol, Cr'nde se relizaron lo'*s proced mientos. La loma de muestra para CIC, se hizo en una submuestra de 
niros mayores de dos aKos los cuales fueron seleccionados 
aleaboriamente. El tamaRo de esta submuestra es equivalente a 25 
% de la muestra para anAlisis de retinal. 
B.3) OPERACIONALIZACION:
 
Para la toma de muestras de laboratorio se establecieron 
centros de operaciones an las comunidades. Para los grupos I y 3 
se establecieron dos centro operacionales por grupo y para los 
grupo 2 y 4 un centro per grupo. En esbos centros se acondicion6 
un lugar para inscripci6n de niRos, dos o tres -lugares para 
extracci6n de muestras de sangre, un lugar para CIC y un lugar 
para centrifugaci6n y separaci6n de plasmas.
 
B.4) CONSERVACION Y ALMACENAMIENTO DE MUESTRAS:
 
El manejo de muestras de laboratorio una vez centrifugadas y 
aeparados los plasmas, fueron conservadas en hieleras de duroport 
y entregadas dos veces al dia al Laboratorio Central, del MSP, 
donde fueron almacenadas a -20 C. Estas muestras serAn 
trasladadas a un congelador a -70 C (segin informaci6n del jefe 
del laboratorio. De los sujetos a quienes se tom muesbra para 
citologia de impresi6n conJuntival, se hizo un duplicado de 
plasma para anAlisis de retinal en el laboratorio de CESSIAN, 
Guatemala.
 
G) RESULTADOS: 
La igecuci6n de la linea basal sE 11ev6 a cabo 
saltisfactoriamente. Hubo muy buena aceptaci6n por .parte de las 
comunidades, tanto para la toma de muestras de sangre como de 
CIC. S increment6 01 Lamao de muestra, en ambos indicadores. 
En retinal, de un nmerc estimado de 400 se aument6 a 538 y en 
CIC de tOO se aumento a 144, lo que representa una aumento de 35 
15 % re:=pectivamente. En el aneo 3, se especifica el nAmero 
de sujeto en cada comunidad. 
Con respecto a los anklisis de retin'l, que no fue un

Laboratorio Central, del MSP, bajo Ila responsabilidad de la 
Licenciade Ingrid de Rivera. Debido a que la t&cnica utilizada 
an este laboratoric y el de CESSIAM son diferentes I Metcdos de 
Lastagnani y Bieri respectivamente), se discuti6 la utilidad de 
tener una estandarizaci6n interlaboratorios; para lo cual deberia 
nor anall zado un set de muestras per ambos laboratorios y 
comparar los resulLados. Esta actividad esLaria bajo la 
responsabi lidad de la Licda. M.E. Romero, en CESSSIAM y de la

Una limitante del Laboratorio Central es que no cuenta con

 APPENDIX #5A Cover Letter and Report 
to IEF/CeSSIAM from 
NCSU 
September 3, 1991 
To: 	 Noel W. Solomons (CeSSIAM)
 
Jack Blanks & John Parrows (IEF)
 
From: 	 Steve Schwartz 
Subject: 	 Continuation of the Guatemalan Plant Analyses 
You should have with this letter the report of the three plants 
for provitamin A carotenoids. I hope you are as pleased with the 
results as I am. Please call if you have any questions or concerns 
related to the results or the report. The only data which is not 
included are the spectral scans of the carotenoids and other pigments 
present in the plant tissues. These are stored in our computor if you 
need a hard copy. 
As I mentioned in my last letter, unfortunately, Amy has 
moved on to work under the direction of another faculty member in 
the Department. She had previously committed to a project and I 
only enticed her to come early for the summer to analyze 
carotenoids. She will be unable to work "part-time" on the project as 
Noel suggested since only one payroll check can be collected from the 
University. This is also true for my other students. Each is supported 
on a grant or contract and therefore any time spent elsewhere has to 
be accounted for or the project (and graduation) must be extended. 
Only my time is flexible and free to all projects! 
Given the above constraints, I suggest we consider supporting a 
graduate student to undertake the remainder of the project. 
Considering the magnitude of the plants to be analyzed and the 
information needed on the effect of cooking and preparation as well 
as the carotenoids present in entire Guatemalan meals, I can easily 
see how the project can develop into an M.S. thesis, especially if we 
include data on the presence and formation of cis isomers and 
information 	 on other endogenous carotenoids. An added benefit to 
this approach is that a dedicated individual is involved from start to 
-,W I finish. Samples could be shutteled -from Guatemala to Raleigh as Noel 
suggested and analyses and typical meals could be prepared. If fresh 
tissues are needed, the M.S. student could conduct the extractions -in 
Guatemala. (I'm not convinced the data obtained from fresh samples 
will differ significantly from those tissues immediately blanched and 
frozen). 
It is possible that a new M.S. student could be recruited to 
begin in January. The big question is funding, Two years support is* 
necessary since an M.S. student takes at least that long to coniplete 
our program. Given a well defined project such as this, I'm confident 
that it would be completed on schedule. Stipends are set at $10,000 
to $11,000/year. Add on costs for HPLC columns, solvents and 
supplies gives a rough figure of $15,000/year not including 
overhead. I realize this is expensive, however, funds to conduct the 
project in pieces with part-time student labor will also cost. I 
honestly believe so much more can be gained via a graduate student 
project. 
I look forward to hearing from you. 
P.S. Noel -Thanks to you and Yoli for the Guatemalan beans. We will 
enjoy them. Hope Yoli had an enjoyable trip and arrived safely. Analysis of Provitamin A Carotenoids in Guatemalan Plants

prepared by:
 
Amy Corbett & Steven J. Schwartz
 
North Carolina State University
 Materials and Methods 
Sample Information 
Each of the three vegetables (carrots, sweet potatoes, and 
macuy) were prepared in Guatemala by selecting 18 samples of each; 
six fresh, blanching six 2 minutes, and blanching six 5 minutes. The 
samples were immediately frozen and packed on dry ice the next 
day to be transported by air for approximately 12 hours. Upon 
arrival, the samples were placed in a walk-in freezer until extraction. 
Moisture Analysis 
Moisture analysis for each vegetable was performed by 
combining 10.0 grams of each of the 6 samples and 60.0 ml of water 
and the mixture pureed. Ten grams of the puree were weighed and 
placed in a Fisher Isotemp forced draft oven at 600 C for 12 hours. 
Samples were then dried in a National vacuum drying oven, model 
5831, at 70 0 C,-9OkPa, for 24 hours. All moisture analyses were 
performed in duplicate. 
Extraction Procedures 
Each sample was extracted using the following procedure. First 
30.0 grams of the sample was combined with 3.0 grams of CaCo3 and 
30.0 ml of deionized water and pureed. Then 10.0 grams of the 
puree was immediately combined with 25.0 ml of methanol. The 
solution was filtered with Whatman filter paper #1 and#42 and the 
filtrate was set aside. The filter cake was combined with 50.0 ml of 
hexane:acetone (1:1) and left for 1 minute. The solution was 
tissumized in a Tekmar tissumizer for 1 minute and refiltered. The extraction was repeated using 50.0 ml of hexane:acetone (1:1), 1 
minute of tissumizing, and refiltered using the same filter paper as 
before. The hexane:acetone filtrates were combined with the 
methanol filtrate in a 500 ml separatory funnel with 10.0 ml of wash 
water. The top hexane layer was washed twice with 10.0 -ml of 
deionized water. The concentrated hexane extract was next diluted 
up to 100.0 ml with hexane except for the sweet potato samples. The 
sweet potato was brought up to 50.0 ml since the extracts were 
already fairly dilute. For storage, 2 ml of the extract was syringe 
filtered using nylon filters from Micron Separations, Inc., 0.45 
micron, 3mm size. Extracts were stored in 1 ml glass vials, foil 
wrapped, under N2, at -18'C prior to analysis by HPLC. The 
extraction procedures were similar to that outlined by Chandler and 
Schwartz (1987). Recovery studies were performed by adding a 
known amount of B-carotene standard obtained from Sigma Chemical 
Co. 
HPLC Procedures 
Extracts were injected using an automatic injector from 
Waters Assoc., Model 712. The pump used was a Waters, Model 510 
and the column was a Zorbax ODS 4.6mm x 25cm (Dupont). 
Absorbance reading were measured at 450nm using a Linear TM 
lVis 200 detector set at a range of .02 (AUFS), rise time of 1 see, and 
using the -visible lamp. The results were integrated on a Macintosh 
Plus computer using the Rainin Dynamax ME, version 1.2, software 
package. Qualitatively, all samples were screened for provitamin A 
carotenoids using a Waters Associates Model 990 photodiode array 
detector. Quantitative HPLC analysis of the samples was performed 
by injecting 15.0 pl of the hexane extracts into a mobile phase 
consisting of methanol:acetonitrile:chloroform (42.5:42.5:15) at a flow 
rate of 1.5 mI/min. All solvents used were purchased from Fisher 
Scientific, and were ACS certified grade. The mobile phase was filtered and deairated using a PTFE, type 1.0, MicronSep Membrane 
filter. 
Preparation of standards 
The external standards , Beta-carotene Type I and Alpha­
carotene Type V, were purchased by Sigma Chemical Co. and 
prepared for the standard curves by serial diluting a *concentrated 
solution in hexane to obtain a five point calibration curve 
encompassing the range of sample extracts to be analyzed. The 
absorbance readings were measured using a Shimadzu UV-240 
spectrophotometer. The Alpha-carotene concentrations were 
calculated from the absorbance readings at 446nm using an E1 % 
value of 2730 (Zscheile,1942). The Beta-carotene concentration 
calculations used an E1 % value of 2592 and the wavelength of 
453nm (Isler,1956). 
Results and Discussion 
HPLC chromatograms monitored at 450 nm and photodiode 
array data indicated that the provitamin A carotenoids present in the 
sample extracts were alpha and beta-carotene. No other provitamin 
A compounds were detected from the three plants. Figures 1, 2 & 3 
are typical HPLC chromatograms for sweet potatoe, carrot and 
macuy, respectively. The photodiode array chromatogram is 
representative for an extract of macuy (Figure 4). The early eluting 
peaks shown in Figure 4 are solvent peaks followed by non­
provitamin A carotenoid xanthophylls and two chlorophylls, 
chlorophyll b and a.. Calibration curves for the two provitamin A 
carotenoids are shown in Figures 5 & 6. Both indicate excellent 
linearity in detector response. 
Table 1 and 2 list the average beta and alpha carotene 
concentrations and the standard deviations for the samples analyzed on a wet weight and dry basis, respectively. Retinol equivalents and 
the range of retinol equivalents (low-high) are also calculated. Table 
3 lists the solids content (moisture analysis results) data. The "raw 
data" is also included at the end of the report. 
The quantities found for the provitami A content of the plant 
tissues were all within reasonable expected values. Deviations among 
samples were noted however attributed to the differences between 
varieties sampled, potentially growing conditions and biological 
variability. The deviation between samples was most evident in the 
sweet potatoes which had a non-homogeneous appearance in color 
ranging from white to pale orange. The B-carotene content on 
average was below typical U.S. varieties. Whereas these ranged 
around 5 RE units on a wet weight basis the U.S. sweet potatoe 
varieties are on average higher in provitamin value with a RE value 
around 8.8 RE units (Adams,1975). The variability between carrot 
samples was also great not only between cooking times but also 
within them. Some samples had poor yields of beta and alpha 
carotene while others were higher than the average U.S. samples. 
Another interesting note is the ratio between the beta and alpha 
carotene changed between samples such that in some samples beta 
content was higher and in others alpha carotene predominated. On 
average, the carrots had an RE value of 23 units (wet weight) which 
is higher than the 11 RE units some U.S. carrots (Adams,1975). The 
macuy samples had good consistency of B-carotene content with the 
5 minute blanch treatment having greater RE values than the carrots. 
In comparing macuy with a similar leafy vegetable such as spinach, 
the macuy had a higher solids content of approximately 20% whereas 
spinach is only 8%. In regard to total carotene content, macuy 
samples averaged approximately 25 RE units (wet weight) where 
spinach is only 8 RE units (Adams,1975). Therefore, macuy and 
carrots both seem to be good sources of provitamin vitamin A. Sweet 
potatoes are also well known for their high beta-carotene content, 
however orange varieties and those with few white mutations should 
be selected for consumption. 
to-I
 The difference of carotene content between cooking times 
shows the 5 minute blanch treatment yielding the highest amount. 
This' is because the cooked flesh responds best to the extraction 
treatment and recovery of the carotene is more efficient. Another 
reason probably lies in the storage of the fresh vegetables. The fresh 
vegetables were received in a frozen condition so they were kept in 
this state until extraction. Since they did not undergo any heat 
treatment prior to freezing, enzymes were active to degrade the 
vitamins present. Ideally, only the 2 or 5 minute blanch vegetables 
should be considered for an accurate provitamin A measurement, 
since they were properly handled and stored. Recovery studies 
yielded on average a 102% recovery of B carotene for the three 
vegetables.

Page 15 Prepared by Dr. Carmen Yolanda Lopez APPENDIX #5B, Report by Dr. Carmen 
Yolanda Lopez 
Project "PROVITA" Increasing the availability of dietary vitamin A to under 
six years old though natural plant food sources of provitamin A; Human and 
tecchnical resource development, community-level inquiry and information 
dissemination. 
This project was developed as a coperative agreements between the 
International Eye Fundation and the Office of Nutrition of the J.S. Agency for 
International Development. 
In Guatemala C.A., the counterpart executors of the project are: 
1)The I.E.F. fiel staff based at the Medical Division of the National Committee 
for the Blind and Deaf of Guatemala (NCBD), and 2) Center for Studies of 
Sensory Impairment, Aging and Metabolism, (CeSSIAM). 
Activity has two component: 
2. Developing accurate chemical analysis for the total vitamin A activity 
(Beta-carotene and other provitamin A active carotenoids) of plant food 
Important to the rural food system of Guatemalans identified by two studies 
conducted in Guatemala, one within CeSSIAM and one by the IEF field staff. 
Local Staff: Carmen Yolanda Lopez Palacios. MD. 
Collaborators: Noel W.Solomons. MD. (CeSSIAM) 
* Steven Schwartz. PhD Associate professor, and the Ammy Corbet. 
Laboratory: Room 200* Department of Food Science. North Carolina State-
University, Raleigh, NC. USA. 
OBJETIVES. 
1) To determine the content of total vitamin A activity in the three 
carotene-containning foods for the intervention (Carrot, Sweet Potato and 
Quilete, "Macuy* or Hierba Mora.) 
2) To determine, with the quality accuracy for inclusion in published 
food tables, the total vitamin Aactivity of up to 37 additional domestic 
(vegetables) and wild (green herbs) plants identified in anthropological 
surveys as relevant to the food-systems of rural Guatemala (Alta Verapaz). 
ANTECEDENT. 
The general list of 40 carotene-containing food shown to be important
in rural food-systems of Guatemala either in the USAID financed study by Mr. William Scott in Alta Verapaz, Zacapa and Santa Rosa, and confirmed by
the ISRC sponsored study in Alta Verapaz by Ms. Sarah Booth and Carmen 
Yolanda Lopez Palacios MD. 
MATERIALS AND METHODS: 
SAMPLE COLLECTION: 
Samples for nutrient analysis were collected during the rainy season; 
from the Alta verapaz, Coban and the Guatemala city. 
If feasible, all samples will be collected atthe same time of the day. 
The nutrient content of a green vegetables is determined in part by
the soil conditions, climatic conditions and stress; An is heterogeneous 
between diferent parts of the plant. 
Therefore to obtain an adequate representation for nutrient analysis a 
composite sample of 2 1plants will be collected for each species 
identified in the diet, with a minimun of 500 grams collected for each 
sample. Only those parts of the plant that are consumed in the diet will be 
collected. To avoid enzymatic and oxidative destruction of vitamins due to 
damage and other factors, each sample were cleaned, weighed, fresh or 
blanched (steam for 2 and 5 mins) and placed in sterile plastic bags, and 
them inmediately frozen. 
These will be transfered in a frozen state to Guatemala city, transported 
back to the capital where they were stored in dry ice, where the samples
will be prepared for the laboratory analysis 
In Guatemala city will be collected a three species for the Carrot, Sweet 
potato and Quilete, "Macuy", or Hierba mora; in triplicate for the cleaned,
blanched for the two and five minutes, whit steam and nature form, before
 
weighed, placed in sterile plastic bags and then inmediately froze and will be
 
prepared for analysis; 110 Frozen samples collected during the first periods
will be air shipped to North Carolina State University, and vitamin A alanysis
will be performed.
 
PROCESSING OF SAMPLES:
 
3 Vegetables processing:
 
Carrot, Sweet Potato and Quilete, "Macuy" or Hierba Mora.
 
6 samples fresh for each vegetable and freezer at -20 oC.
 
6 samples blanched for 2 minutes and freezer at -20 oC.
 
6 samples blanched for 5 minutes and freezer at -20 oC.
 EXTRACTION PROCEDURES: 
Each sample was extracted using the following procedure. 
Thirty grams of the sample was combined with 3 grams of CaCo3 and 30 ml 
of dionized water and pureed in a Black &Decker Handy Chopper. Ten grams 
of the puree was immediately combined with 25 ml of Methanol. The 
solution was filtered with Whatman filter parer # 1and and the filtrate #42 
was set aside. The filter cake was next combined with 50 ml of 
Hexane:Acetone (1:1), and left standing for 1minute. The solution was 
tissumized in a Tekmar tissumizer for 1minute and refiltered. Then the 
extraction was repeated using 50 ml of hexane:acetona (1:1), 1minute of 
tissumized, and refiltered using the same filter parer as before. The

SAMPLE OF ANALISYS BY HPLC. 
HPLC Equipment 
The samples were injected using an automatic injector by Waters Assoc, model 712. The punp used was a Waters, model 510 and the column 
was a Zorbex ODS model made by DuPont, measuring 4.6 mm* 25 cm. The absorbance was read at 450 nm using a. Linear TM UVis 200 detector set at a range of .02 (AUFS), rise time of 1 sec, and using the visible lamp. The results were integrated on a Macintosh Plus computer using the RaininDynamax ME, version 1.2, software packge. 
HPLC procedures­HPLC analysis of the samples was done by injecting 15 ul of the 
hexane extracts into a mobile pnase of (MeOH: ACN: CHC13) 
methanol:acetonitrile:chloroform (42.5:42.5:15) at a flow rate of 1.5 ml/min 
with a pressure of 1000 PSI All chemicals used were purchased by Fisher, 
and were ACN certified grade. The mobile phase was filtered and degased 
using a PTFE, type 1.0, MicronSep Membrane filter. The external standards, 
Beta-carotene type I and Alpha-carotene Type V, were purchased by Sigma 
Chemical Co. and absorbance reading toher on a Shimadzu UV-240 
spectrophotometer. The Alpha-carotene concentrated was calculated from 
absorbance reading at 446 nm using and the E1I volue of 2730 (Zschelile, 
1942). The Beta-carotene used an E 1% volue of 2592 at the wavelenth of 
453 nm (Isler, 1959).

PROCEDIMIENTO:
 
Estabilizacion de muestras de alimentos para analisis de laboratorio:
 * Recoleccion do la muestra: 
Para obtener un valor representative mas exacto de los diferentes 
nutrientes contenidos en un alimento de origen vegetal, se procede a 
recolectar la muestra do las diforentes areas do la parcela o cultivo, sin tenor 
predileccion por determinada caracteristica como tamano, color etc. 
Teniendo presente el dictamen de los agricultores o agronomos a cargo o bien 
nuestro propio criterio para saber si el vegetal esta ya on condiciones do ser 
consumido como alimento. 
Esto no quiere decir necesariamente que la parte comestible del vegetal haya
1legado a su madurez, pues las condiciones en que es usado y la forma 
culinaria en que se prepara son impuestas por las costumbres de la 
comunidad. 
Recoleccion de la muestra. 
Esto puede hacerce en un mercado local, casa particular o do un vendedor 
ambulante, en este caso se selecciona la muestra de las diferentes partes del puesto de venta o del recipiente en que esta es recolectada o acarreada. 
Generalmente un promedio de 600 gramos es suficiente para efectuar las ostabilizaciones, so anotan todos los datos que el vendedor pueda darnos. 
So profiere efoctuar las colectas on horas de la manana, a fin de obtener las muestras de vegetales lo mas fresco posible y que no so afecten por accion 
de los rayos solares on horas mas fuertes y so desifidraten mas rapido. Por lo quo so sugiere efectuar la colecta a la misma hora del dia y 10 mas temprano posible. 
Si so obtienen las muestras de un supermorcado o tienda, tenemos quoserciorarnos do que los vegetales son la mas fresco posible y no hayan estado almaconados por mucho tiempo, o sufrido cambios bruscos do luz; oidgeno ytemperatura, ya quo esto afocta grandomente su composicion vitaminica.. 
A simple vista el vegetal debe lucir con una textura adecuada, color brillante y grado do hidratacion optimo antes de efectuar el analisis. 
Anotacion de Datos. 
Para este fin se hace use de una hoja especial de records, cuadernos detrabajo o formularios do identificacion (ficha recolectora do dates) en los cuales so anota la techa y hora de recoleccion de la muestra, numero do muestra on orden suscesivo de la numoracion, numero de codigo paraanalisis de laboratore, El nonabre comun usado en la comunidad para cada uno do los vegetales en particular (vulgar), clasificacion botanica y nombre en ingles El sitio o lugar de la colecta y el sitio de origen de la planta (pais, ciudad, departamento, finca, aldea etc.) So anota la parte de la planta
colectada por ejemplo: raiz, tallos, hojas, flores, frutos, entera; El precio de la 
muestra por unidad de venta: manojo, unidad, libra, onzas etc. 
Peso de la muestra en gramos (total comprado) o peso bruto, el peso neto o 
porcion comestible y la porcion no comestible para calcular el porcentaje de 
desgaste o tara. -Se prefiere trabajar on base a 100 gramos de porcion
comestible para el analists do laboratorio o do sus equivalentes cuando es necesatio para los calculos finales. 
Se buscan y se anotan otros datos disponibles, siempre que tengan algun
interes practico, por ejemplo la frecuencia de 1luvias en la localidad (medida 
en pulgadas), calidad del terreno, altitud, clase de fertilizantes utilizados para
mejorar los cultivos si existe un sistema de irrigacion o cualquier otra 
modificacion efectuada, para lo cual es necesatio ponerse en contacto con 
personas que conozcan de cultivos, como agricultores, agronomos etc. asi 
come do los usos locales del alimento para lo cual so entrevista a jefes do 
cocina o amas de casa. 
* Descripcion del vegetal para analisis: So describe si la muestra esta cruda 
o sea materiales frescos o si se les efectuo algun otto procedimiento como por
ejemplo el blanqueado al vapor por 2 y 5 minutos, para lo cual se pone el peso neto en gramos de la porcion comestible en fresco y el peso en gramosdel alimento post blanqueado, para medir el grado de hidratacion o 
deshidratacion quo sufre ol vegetal con esto tratamiento. 
Procedimiento do estabilizacion de la muestra. 
Si se esta trabajando en una aldea o cacerio, esto so improviza y para
obtener mejores resultados se selecciona una pieza con buena ventilacion e 
iluminacion adecuada, escrupulosamente limpia. En ena mesa de buen
 tamano se instala el equipo portatil Antes de tratar la muestra es de mucho
 interes para los archivos do la institucion fotografiarla co pelicula de color.
 
Tratamiento mecanico de la muestra:
 
a) Se pesa la muestra tal como fue recogida, sin lavar ni quitar partes que
 por cualquier circunstancia no se comen, se anota este peso en la hoja de
 records (Peso Bruto). Representa el total comprado.
b) Seguidamonte so selecciona la parto comestible, 
 si en esta parto
seleccionada entran pericarpio u hojas, so lavan perfectamente on agua
corriente para quitar toda sustancia que pueda alterar los datos finales, se enjuagan en agua destilada y so dejan secar a la sombra en la mesa de trabajo por una o dos horas, otro procedimiento mas rapido es estilarlas en un colador de plastico y hacerles una ligera presion con toallas de papel absorvente para elnlainar el exceso de agua. Una vez bien seca la muestra se 
hace una segunda pesada total o dato de rendimlento (Peso Neto) representa 
la porcion-comestible. 
c) Se efectua el calculo de porcentaje de desgaste o sea se pesa todo ol 
material que sobro o porcion no comestible y se relaciona con el total 
comprado menos la porcion comestible. 
d) So coloca el material fresco ya pesado on bolsas plasticas esteriles, con 
cierre hermetico, retirando todo el aire presente dentro de ellas y 
rotulandolas con su respectiva identificacion para el analisis posterior de la 
muestra, so colocan inmediatamente on las hieleras con hielo seco y so 
mantienen congeladas para el transporte, luego se transfieren al frizer 7 so 
mantienen on refrigeracion. a -2 oC hasta el momento do su analisis on el 
laboratorio respectivo. 
e) A las muestras on duplicado so les ofectua 0l procedimiento do 
blanqueado, quo es necesario para dotener ol proceso do oxidacion de los 
vejetales, que al ser cortados y ser expuestos a la luz, oxigeno y diferentes 
temperaturas sufren cambios de hidratacion, color y degradacion de las 
vitaminas, especialmento la vitamina A,los carotenoides se destruyen por 
accion enzimatica de la lipoxigenasa presente en los vegetales. 
De la muestra de vegetal fresco (crudo), s6 pesan 100 granios de porcion 
comestible; Previamente se pone agua en los 2/3 inferiores de una olla de 
peltre y so ileva a obullicion a temporatura do 200 oC. on la parte superior 
so-coloca un colador de malla de metal quo contiene la muestra del vegetal y 
so tapa, dejando un espacio entre el agua que estahirviendo y el colador a 
fin de que reciba el vapor por el tiempo definido (2 Y 5 minutos), luego se 
retira al concluir el intervalo de tiempo fijado proviamente y so sumerge la 
muestra que esta en el colador en un recipiente que contiene agua fria con 
algunos cubos de hielo, por espacio de 5 minutos, 0 10 suficiente para que so 
enfrie, luego so saca y so estila en un colador de plastico y se presiona 
suavemente con una toalla do papol absorvonto para quitarle ol excoso do 
liquido, luego so posa nuevamento la muestra post blanqueado, para anotar 
los cambios por hidratacion o deshidratacion, luego se pone dentro de bolsas 
esteriles con cierre hermetico, debidamente rotuladas usando un marcador 
permanente con su respectivo numero de identificacion y otros datos 
necesarios, inmediatamente despues se colocan en hieleras con hielo seco 
para que se congelen y so mantienen asi para el transporte, luego se 
transfieren al frizer a temperatura de -20 oC. hasta el momento de su 
analisis on el laboratorio rospectivo. 
El procedimiento do blanqueado se puede hacer on la misma forma, solo quo
sumergiendo directamente los vegetales on el agua hirviendo y se mantienen 
ei ebullicion par el tiempo definido previamente, se'ha doctimentado que 
este metodo aumenta la destruccion de los cloroplastos, afectando 
directamente los valores de las vitaminas, especialmente las hidrosolubles quo pasan a1liquido decoccion, asI como del vegetal (clororilas), quo tinen el agua 	 do dlferentes Intensidades do parte de los pigmentos naturales 
verdes, segun el vegetal procesado. 
Transporte de muestras: 
dentro de e oxegeo do emnto en quo son coloctadas so mantionon on la sombra o cient pventiladoS Paa oxlgeno a in do 	que no les atecte la temperatura luz y no provocar cambios en su estructura, grado do hidratacion y valor flutriuvo. 
Se utilizan hieleras do duroport con tapadera o preferiblemente de plasticocon cierr hermetic 0 utilizando hielo soco para su transporte, el cual debeSOr no mayor do 48 hemas desde su colcta, so emplea vohiculo y avion Par-adistancia mas largas. En ol laboratorido -	so colocan, onel frizer a tomporatura 20 oC. y so mantion5n asi hasta ol memento de su analisis, debe do ser mayor do 	 cual no 1S dias Para muestras frescas y no mayor 	 de 6 meses Par-a vegetales Procesados ya quo so sabe quo continua el proceso de Oxidacion por accion la onzimatca.

METODOS DE SEPARACION: 
Los metodos disponibles para HPLC en el analisis de carotenoides 
estan clasificados en 4 grupos de acuerdo al sistema de solventes y
absorvancia utilizada. 
* Utilizar el mas combeniente, slempre y cuando se guarden las condiciones 
apropiadas para dicho analisis 
A. Sistema isocratico de solventos &n fase normal do absorvancia: 
Emplea dos columnas y dos solventes isocraticos combinados para la 
separacion de Alfa, Beta-caroteno y criptoxantin. 
b. Fase normal con sistema de solventes en gradiente. 
Se utiliza para la separacion do compuestos mixtos de carotenoides y 
xantofilas So necesita de un equilibrio constante entre los compuestos a 
separar, por ojemplo on las columnas do silica, utilizadas no so logra una 
clara separacion do los carotenoides, por la doble union y la posicion do los 
isomeros similar a los do la columna, por 10 que no debe emplearse para la 
determinacion de provitaminA. 
Sistema isocratico de solventes en fase reversa:*
 
Este sistema usa como materiales de la columna Octadecilsileno
 
(apolar) unido a la silica, el mecanismo do retencion es en fase reversa en la 
cromatografia, con interaccion hidrofobica entro ol hidrocarbono no polar, la 
capa do solucion y la fase movil relativamente polar. Bajo este sistoma las 
fuerzar hidrofobicas son comparables con la particion entre los solventes 
miscibles que estan operando; Estas fuerzas dan una lejana y menor 
destruccion lonica con las fuerzas polares do la cromatografia convenclonal; 
slendo separados los pigmentos a una baja presion dentro do las colunmas. C Los sistemas isocraticos con una adecuada seleccion de la columna y 
solventes, es posible la resolucion de ia mayoria de los carotenoides y 
determinarlos como actividad de vitamina A. 
D. Columna de fase reversa y sistema de solkventes do gradiente: 
Permite la separacion do otros pigmentos fotosinteticos en sistomas 
lineares do gradiente; Este sistoma do solventes, resuelve la sdparacion do los 
pigmentos del cloroplasto; La separacion de los isomeros-cis y los productos 
de la oxidacion. Rondas isocraticas de 10 um Rp 18 Columna con soluciones 
de metanol, acetonitrilo (2 5:75) permiten una completa resolucion de las 
clorofilas (Ay 3) y del D-caroteno. Requieren de un reequilibrio del sistema 
y del gradients on fase reversa. La aplicacion de otros radicales, disminuye 
el tiempo de retencion; RCM C 16 es el metodo que ha demostrado un alto 
potencial para la determinacion y analisis do provitamina A, como metodo do 
rutina. 
* Metodo para la determinacion de carotenoides por Cromatografia Liquida 
de Alta Presion HPLC 
DETERMINACION: Requiere de una solucion de estandard de caroteno 
inyectado en el sistema cerrado de solventes en la columna, tiempo de 
retencion, area del pico del cromatograma y la muestra del estandard 
recuperado dot analisis por HPLC, Picos do pigmentos, como fracciones de la 
muestra, identificados en base al tiempo de retencion y la cuantificacion del 
area del pico del cromatograma en el HPLC. 
Condiciones de operacion para la determinacion de carotenoides: 
- Instrumento. HPLC 
- Columna- Zorbax ODS, 4.6 mm IDx 25 cm. 
- Faso movil: Motanol, Acetonitrilo, Cloroformo (42.5:42.5: f5); 
(meOH : acn -CHC13) 
- Rango de flujo- 1.5 cm3/min = 1.5 mI/mi. 
- Presion: ml/min P= 1000 PSI 
- Detector lineal 200 -450 nm. 
- Temperatura- X 25 oC Laboratorio. 
- Volumen de inyeccion de muestra. 15 mm-3 
- Detector UV ABS (250 nm) 0 5 AUFS. 
- Tiempo- 20 minutos 
- Intervalo entre muestras 0. 1 segundos. 
* CROMATOGRAMA:
 - Numero de pico: 
- Tipo de pico: 
- Altura (uv) 
- Area (uv-sec) * 
- Area % 
- Area total %

I. 	Course Description
 I 	 This is an eminently practical course, in which the
 
students will move to a "ladino" community and apply methods
 
and techniques of data collection and analyses within the
 
theoretical and methodological framework of applied
 
anthropological investigation. The faculty member will
 
constantly supervise the work of the students so that they
 will have effective feedback in their training of field 
workers. 
II. Objectives 
That the students: 
A. Understand the importance and the place of field 
work within the context of applied Anthropology.
 
B. Apply techniques and methods of data collection
 
and analysis within the theoretical or specific
 
research project.
 
C. Reflect on the responsibility of the anthropologist to
 the study community and behavior in accord withI professional ethics.

investigation.

of Sensory Impairment, Aging and Metabolism (CESSIAM).

f INTRODUCCION -
La deficiencia de vitamina A es uno de los mayores problemas 
de salud pAblica que enfrenta el mundo actual. Varias 
investigaciones han revelado que en Guatemala este problema ha 
alcanzado proporciones que requieren de atenc16n inmediata. 
Por consiguiente, se han 1levado a cabo varios programas a 
fin de minimizar las consecuencias que este problema puede 
implicar para la salud general de la poblaci6n, en particular de 
los niAos menores de seis aMos. 
Una de las medidas que se han implementado en numerosas 
regiones del mundo consiste en administrar megadosis de vitamina 
A a la poblaci6n afectada. Sin embargo, en los 01timos aRos se 
ha determinado que Asta no constituye la soluc16n mAs apropiada 
para eliminar el problema a largo plazo. 
De ahi que se hallan propuesto programas destinados a 
promover el consumo de alimentos ricos en vitamina A, pues los 
cambios en la dieta son un medio esencial para la soluci6n 
permanente del problema. 
Actualmente, IEF, el Comitl Nacional Pro-Ciegos y Sordos y 
CeSSIAM, con la colaboraci6n de la oficina de nutrici6n de la 
AID, estAn realizando un estudio multidisclplinario con el objeto 
de determinar los hAbatos alimentarios y la deficiencia de 
vitamina A en tres aldeas del municipie de Santa Cruz Naranjo, 
deparatamento de Santa Rosa. Las tres comunidades elegidas son 
Teocinte, El Naranjo y Don Gregorio. 
Posteriormente, se distribuirAn tres tipos de alimentos con 
altas concentraciones de vitamina A: ranahoria, quilete y camote. 
En una de las comunidades, se regalarAn los alimentos en 
cantidades suficientes pwra cubrir las necesidades de las 
familias con nifos preescolares, menores de sems abos. En otra, 
la cantidad de alimentos distribuida estarA destinada 6nicamente 
a los preescolares. Finalmente, la tercera aidea se uLilizarA 
como grupo control, per 10 q", no so distribuirA ningdn alimento 
entre la poblac1dn, 
Hasta el momento, la investigacion se encuentra en su etapa 
inicial, la cual se divide en dos estudios. Por un lado, se estA 
real arndo una evaluaci6n nutricional de una muestra de la 
poblaci6n. AdemAs, se l1ev6 a cabo un estudin antropoldgico 
acerce de los hibitos alimentarios de ias Lres aldeas, en su
 
contento cultural y socio-econ6mico. 
La investiqaci6n antropo36gica estuvo a cargo de 3a 
licenciada Eugenia Sagn2 de Tejada, quien contd con ia
 
colaboraci6n de seas estudiantes de antropologia de la
 
Universidad del Valle de Guatemala. El informe que se presenta a
 
continuacin contiene los datos obtenados durante la
 
investigaci6n de campo que se 1lev6 a cabo del 17 de junio al 12 
de julio del aMo en curso. Objetivos I 
1) Describir los hAbitos alimentarios de los preescolares de las 
aldeas estudiadas. 
2) Describir la relaci6n que existe entre diversas creencias y 
actitudes y la alimentaci6n de los niRos preescolares. 
3) Estudiar los hAbitos alimentarios de las familias en el 
contexto cultural y socio-econ6mico de las comunidades 
investigadas. I. METODOLOGIA
 
Un equipo conformado por un antropdlogo, un nutricionista y 
un m~dico elabor6 un instrumento de investigaci6n que consta de 
cuatro secciones: Beneficio Econ6mico, HAbitos Alimentarios, 
Creencias y Datos Socio-Econ6micos (ver ap~ndice I). 
Se realird una prueba piloto en un Area peri-urbana de la 
capital: Ciudad Peronia. Se entrevist6 a varias madres de 
familia para determinar las posibles fallas del cuestionario. En 
base a esta experiencia, se realizaron las modificaciones 
pertinentes al instrumento. 
El grupo de estudiantes de antropologia se traslad6 a Santa
 
Cruz Naranjo, en donde permanecieron per espacio de cuatro 
semanas, del 17 de junio al 12 de julio, bajo la direcci6n de la 
licenciada Eugenia Sa~nz de Tejada. 
Se decidi6 que la muestra poblacional utilizada en la 
investigaci6n estaria conformada par la totalidad de hogares can 
ni~os preescolares de las tres aldeas. El t~rmino preescalar se 
defini6 coma todos los ni~os de menores de seis a~os y media. 
El grupo de estudiantes se dividi6 en parejas para realizar
 
simullAneamente el trabajo en las tres comunidades. Se visitd 
cada hogar de la comunidad, con el objeto de determinar la 
presencia de preescoleres y poder pasar el cuestionaro. 
Adicionalmente, se intent6 obtener informaci6n adicional sabre el 
contento cultural y socio-econ6mico de las comunidades, 
utilizando el m6todo de observaci6n participativa y entrevistas
 
informales. Sin embargo, no se profundizo en este aspecto de la 
investigaci6n par falta de tiempo= 
Se logr6 entrevistar a la gran mayoria de familias con 
preescolares. Unicamente se omitaeron aquellos cases aislados, 
en donde las personas se negaron efmresamente a participar en el 
estudio. 
Posteriormente, en la caudad se proceda6 a la codificaci6n e 
ingreso de los datos a una computadora, utilizando el programa 
DBase III Plus. Por raones ajenes a nuestra voluntad, este 
trabajo se emtendi6 mAs de 10 pianificado. 
La informaci6n se proces6 can el programa Epi-Info, para 
obtener los resultados finales de la investicac6n. Este informe 
constituve on anAlasis preliminer de estos i1tmos. Ademls, 
incluve los datos obtenidos en el campo en visitas y 
conversaciones can los pobladores. II. DESCRIPCION BEOBRAFICA
 
El municipio de Santa Cruz Naranjo tiene una extensi6n 
territorial de 67 km -y se encuentra en el departamento de Santa 
Rosa. Colinda al norte con Fraijanes, al este con Santa Rosa de 
Lima y Nueva Santa Rosa, al sur con Barberena y al oeste con 
Barberena y Fraijanes. 
El municipio fue fundado el 2 de junio de 1910 y actualmente
 
cuenta con una municipalidad de tercera categoria. Comprende
 
cinco aldeas: El Teocinte, El Naranjo, Don Bregorio, Potrerillos
 
y El Carmen (Censo 1981, Direccibn General de Estadistica).
 
AdemAs, cuenta con varios caserios, fancas y parajes cuya
 
delimitaci6n varia segin las fuentes.
 
Segmn estimaciones del alcalde de la localidad, el municipio
 
tiene una poblaci6n de 10,429 habitantes.

5. Modificaciones en la dieta en caso de embarazo
 
El 77.7" de la! personas entrevistadas manferst6 Que las

6. Modificaciones en la dieta durante la lactancia 
El 63.3% de la poblac±6n afFrm6 que las mujeres camoian de 
dieta mientras estin dando de mamar. Los informanteF sndicaron que durante los primeros 40 dias, las mujeres siguen "la dieta".
 
Segin esta creencia, las madres que estAn amamantando deben comer 
carne y caldo de gallina, en vez de frijoles. Si la madre come 
frijoles, el ombligo del niko no cicatriza. Asimismo, no se 
pueden consumir alimentos considerados "frios", como el aguacate, 
el queso, la coliflor V la pacaya, pues arruinan la leche y 
provocan c6licos en los lactantes.
 
Posteriormente, las muieres pueden empezar a consumir otros 
alimentos. Sin embargo, deben abstenerse de consumir comidas 
"frias", citricos y otras frutas Acidas, como el nance a la piRa, 
mientras estn dando de mamar. En efecto, estas frutas cortan la 
leche a le dan mal sabor. 
Estas costumbres todavia se observan en las comunidades 
estudiadas, pero pudimos constatar que se encuentran mAs 
arraigadas en las generaciones anteriores. Las j6venes 
frecuentemente han escuchado a las muijeres mayores hablar sobre 
estas creencias, pero ya no las conocen a fondo. 
7. Prioridad para servir los alimentos
 
El orden en quc la madre sirve los alimentos a los miembros 
de su hogar no es importante, pues rara vez toda la familia come 
junta. Los padres y los hijos mayores se van temprano a trabalar 
al campo, por lo que desayunan primero. Algunos 1levan su 
"bastimento"; otros regresan a almorzar a la casa, pero alrededor 
de las 14 horas. Los escolares salen un poco m~s tarde en la
 
makana, pero comen al volver de la escuela a medio dia.
 
En la noche, las costumbres varian de hogar a hogar. Sin 
embargo, en los casos en que la familxa se redne para comer, las 
entrevastadas aseguraron que el orden en qua servian los platos 
no tenia importancia. 
En este aspecto, las comunidades estudiadas difieren 
basLante de los pueblos indigenas. No obstante, creemos qua la 
observaci6n directa del desarrollo de las comadas en los propios 
hogares es necesaria para confirmar la informaci6n. 
Las madres de famil a indicaron que allas distribuyen 
equitativamente los alimentos, aun cuando la cantidad de los 
miasmos see muy peque~a- Atras afirmaron que nunca cocinan alguna 
comida que no vaya a alcanzar para toda la familia, pues de asta 
forma evitan pleitos entre los hjos. Solamente un 1V.7 X de la 
poblaci6n afirmo que los niRos tienen prioridad para recibir 
alimenLoss pues de esta manera se trata de contribuir a SU 
desarrollo fisico y mental.

 III. CONCLUSIONES
 
Los alimentos m~s mencionados como parte de la dieta en las 
tres comunidades son el frijol, el quilete, el arror, la pasta, 
los huevos, el pollo y las tortillas. Las verduras, entre ellas 
la zanahoria y el camate, si son conocidas por la poblaci6n. Sin 
embargo, no se consumen en cantidades apropiadas pues no se 
encuentran disponibles en la comunidad. Por lo tanto, podemos
 
esperar que la introducci6n de quilete, zanahoria y camote sea
 
bien recibida per los pobladores.
 
En esta poblaci6n, las creencias y pr~cticas asociadas a las 
categorias de alimentos frios y calientes no se encuentran muy 
arraigadas en la cultura. Por consiguiente, aparentemente este 
factor no obstaculizarA en forma considerable el consumo de los 
alimentos ricos en vitamina A. 
Por otra parte, consideramos que en la segunda etapa de este 
estudio, varias respuestas pueden cambiar. En primer lugar, va 
a aumentar la frecuencia con que se mencione la zanahoria, el 
camote y el quilete como alimentos consumidos, En los hogares 
donde 6stos se distribuyan. Sin embargo, debido a las 
variaciones estacionales de la dieta, serA necesario comparar 
estos datos con los del grupo control. 
Asimismo, la forma de obtenci6n de los alimentos tambidn 
cambiarA, pues se sekalarA que Fe consumen verduras regaladas, en 
los cases correspondientes. 
No creemos que los alimentos distribuidos per el prayecto 
vayan a utili:arse en la preparaci6n de comidas caseras 
destinadas a la venta, pues el porcentaje de mujeres que se 
dedica a esta actividad es demasiado bajo. 
De igual manera, as probable que los alimentos disLribudos 
se diaidan ent-e todos los miembros de la famlia, aen la aldea en 
donde rstos se proporcionen Onicamente a los preescolares. Como 
hemos visto anteriormente, en la mayoria de hogares, la madre 
reparte ins alimentos entre tode la familla. Incl'so, cabs la 
posibilidad de que los preescolares de menor edad no aprovechen 
en absoluto el prcyecto, pues Ia mayoria de ellos no consume mAs 
que leche, caldos y atoles. IV. RECOMENDACIONES
 
Una de las mayores dificultades que enfrentamos en este 
trabajo residi6 en la codificacibn de los datos. En 
investigaciones futuras, Seria conveniente codificar -el 
cuestionario desde su diseio. 
En vista de las variaciones estacionales que probablemente 
sufre la dieta, seria conveniente realizar la segunda etapa de 
esta investigaci6n en la misma &poca del a-o que la primera.
